case_vignette: An otherwise healthy 60-year-old dishwasher presents with asymptomatic green discoloration of his right middle fingernail over a period of 2 months! The discoloration began from the distal margin! He denies wearing gloves while working and reports a tendency to pick at his nails when nervous! On examination, distal onycholysis and green discoloration are present exclusively on the right middle nail plate starting from the distal edge without signs of paronychia! Dermoscopy reveals pigment localization under the nail plate!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a green discoloration on my right middle fingernail that has been there for about 2 months.
Has there been any trauma to the nail or excess moisture exposure?
I've been working as a dishwasher without wearing gloves, so my nail has been exposed to a lot of water.
Does the nail have any other symptoms besides the green discoloration, such as pain, pus, or separation from the nail bed?
The nail is separating from the nail bed, but there is no pain or pus.
Do you have any history of underlying health conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
No, I'm otherwise healthy and not taking any medications.
**Final Diagnosis:** Green nail syndrome (Chloronychia)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports a green discoloration on their right middle fingernail that has persisted for about 2 months. The patient has been employed as a dishwasher and has not used gloves, hence exposing the nail to frequent water contact. There is noted separation of the nail from the nail bed, but the patient reports no pain or pus. The patient confirms being otherwise healthy and is not taking any medications.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Green nail syndrome (Chloronychia) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection.
